Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: A Discourse Analysis of Training Programs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The anthropological research supported by this award will study programs that are trying to broaden the participation of underrepresented groups. Unlike studies that focus on large-scale social programming, this project will look at the effectiveness of smaller, less costly undertakings that concentrate their efforts on training individuals. The overarching research question is whether this more practical approach, which respects individual choice-making and agency, is as effective as larger scale approaches. This is an important question because all societies must sometimes ask their citizens to respond to changing circumstances. Policy makers need to understand the relationship between individual acts and larger social processes in order to bring about the necessary responses.

The research will be undertaken in the United States, using candidate training programs as research sites. The researcher will assess how these programs understand, strategize about, and promote leadership by targeted groups. The researcher will collect data using a combination of ethnographic methods including: participant observation at training sessions; the collection and comparative analysis of discourse collected at programs targeted at different groups; text analysis of training materials; semi-structured interviews with trainers and trainees; and archival research. Findings from the research will contribute to better scientific understanding of how individual agents may or may not produce social transformation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sarah Carson has completed research for her dissertation, supported by the NSF Dissertation Research Improvement Grant. During her funding period, she spent a total of eight months working with two political candidate training programs in Michigan and California. As an anthropologist studying women in United States politics, Carson was interested in how leadership training advances gender parity in public office. She focused specifically on how political party orientation intersected with understandings of women's leadership in training program discourses and practices.

As a participant observer at training sessions and through text analysis of training materials, Carson accomplished her goal of collecting training discourse data and comparing the strategies used by different groups to assess how programs understand and promote women's leadership. She assisted in facilitating training sessions and worked alongside training program advocates between sessions, during which she developed ethnographic understandings of everyday practices at her field sites through informal interaction and observation. The data Carson collected while observing the programs' operations forms the foundation for her argument that training not only provides assistance by imparting nuts and bolts campaign skills, but also can provide social, emotional, and material support to members of groups who have been historically underrepresented in political office that can help offset a lack of access to traditional fundraising and mentorship "boys' club" networks. Carson's involvement in the project had broader impacts outside of her academic work. She developed public communications to highlight program participants from underrepresented backgrounds as a tool for recruitment of leaders who better reflect the diversity of their communities and helped update training program directories to enable participants to more effectively network and find support.

Carson also conducted semi-structured interviews with training program participants during her grant period. She spoke with women about their experiences in elected office and campaigning. She wished to understand how practitioners and those on the ground discuss barriers to women and how candidate training strategies seek to address them. Scholars have identified various barriers to women's political involvement, including institutional factors like the type of electoral system, social norms that favor men in positions of power, and psychological predispositions such as women's relatively lower political ambition. Candidate training strategies like network-building and personal empowerment seek to address some of these challenges, but inherent limitations of individualized training and partisan differences in attitudes toward identity politics complicate their efforts. Examining the practical interventions made by gender equality advocates across the political spectrum helps illuminate changing sociocultural attitudes about women's leadership and how women in politics differentially experience inequality.

Carson's research with these organizations and supplementary observations of other training program workshops form the basis of her dissertation. To be completed in 2021, the dissertation is an important contribution to anthropology because it asserts how individual political training programs work within existing systems and reinforce traditional social norms while also presenting new possibilities and understandings of the relationship between gender and power. The findings contribute to better scientific understanding of how individual agents produce social transformation.
